content: Even though the email accounts use the same domain, each one needs its own SMTP server, as it is the server that determines the sender. Give each a unique description to ensure you assign each appropriately. When done, you should see six incoming servers and six outgoing servers.
creator: davidsk

content:
david said
Even though the email accounts use the same domain, each one needs its own SMTP server, as it is the server that determines the sender. Give each a unique description to ensure you assign each appropriately. When done, you should see six incoming servers and six outgoing servers.


How can I do this, please ?
creator: abufarha989

content: -click tools>account setting and scroll down to Outgoing servers (SMTP) where it displays your SMPT servers. Click the 'add ' button. Create each SMTP server identical to the original one, but each with a different email id. Be sure to give each a different description. -Next, click the account pane for each account and at the bottom is a place to link the account to the appropriate SMPT server. Do that for all six accounts.
creator: davidsk

content:
david قال
-click tools>account setting and scroll down to Outgoing servers (SMTP) where it displays your SMPT servers. Click the 'add ' button. Create each SMTP server identical to the original one, but each with a different email id. Be sure to give each a different description. -Next, click the account pane for each account and at the bottom is a place to link the account to the appropriate SMPT server. Do that for all six accounts.

content: I regret that I cannot identify the specific issue, but the problem remains in the configuration somewhere. I watched the movie several times , but I could not follow the complete thread. content: The profile is the one in the appdata\thunderbird\profiles folder . Check to see if you imported the right one.
creator: davidsk

content: As per instructions on Mozilla help page, I copied the whole folder titled "Thunderbird". 1) Can I import this folder from my usb, or should I first copy it to the Profile folder on my Mac (target pc) and import from there? 2) Should I import the entire "Thunderbird" folder? That is what I did, but import failed. Or do I just choose the "Profile" folder? And in that folder there are 2 folders, 1 called xxxdefault-release and the other called just xxxdefault. Do I need both? (I had several email accounts in my Thunderbird email program.)
creator: sheffner

content: Just selecting the Profile folder also results in a failed import. Just selecting the xxxdefault-release folder also results in a failed import. To confirm: I'm trying to import a profile folder that I was using on a Windows 10 pc, into a Mac Air (Ventura OS). I copied the Windows Thunderbird profile folders to a USB and from the Thunderbird installed on my Mac I selected "import from another installation" and pointed it to the Profile folder on my USB. Import failed.
creator: sheffner

content:
First, if profile is smaller than 2 gig, tools>export and tools>import is easiest solution. Second, you can confirm the name of active profile by browsing the text file at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini that little file is what tells thunderbird which profile to open. Third, I don't know MAC at all. I know copying the Thunderbird folder works for Windows, but I defer to others on whether that works for MAC. For a MAC, my suggestion would be to - confirm via profiles.ini the proper profile - copy that to a USB stick - on the MAC, click tools>import>importfromanotherinstallation>selectaprofilefolder

If there are no problems in profile, I think that should work. I hope you copied the profile to USB when THunderbird was NOT running. Otherwise, you have a corrupted profile.
creator: davidsk

content: Profiles folder is 11.1 MB. Unfortunately, import failed again. I'm out of options.
creator: sheffner

content:
No, you can use profile manager. That feature was designed for this function. - copy the profile to anywhere on the MAC - start thunderbird - click help>moretroubleshootinginformation - scroll down to profiles and click 'about:profiles' - click the 'create profile' button - click 'next' and on next window do two things in sequence: 

  1. create a name, eg PROFILE    2. then click the browse button to locate and select the profile you copied and select to use.
creator: davidsk

content: This seems to have worked. I say "seems" as the imported profile is now the one in use. However, none of my emails, accounts or folders are visible/accessible. Thunderbird opens the Welcome to Thunderbird page and invites me to set up my email accounts. (Sigh). I do appreciate the time and trouble you took to answer my many dummy questions, especially as you are not a Mac user yourself.
creator: sheffner

content: Can you see the account on the MAC, in the equivalent of FIle Explorer? When created the copy on windows 10, was Thunderbird running at the time? If so, the profile itself is corrupted. I suggest starting over if in doubt. The correct windows profile is named in c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini Copy just that one profile when thunderbird is not running Then repeat the process of putting it on MAC and starting thunderbird with help>moretroubleshootinginformation,,etc. That would at least assure you that you had everything.
creator: davidsk

content:
David, you are a saint. I started afresh and it worked. When I opened the profile folder I had been trying to import from, I saw it was missing the address book file, so was obviously corrupted. I copied over only the default-release profile folder and imported it directly from Thunderbird on my Mac from the USB, and it worked. All my accounts and old emails are now on my Mac.

Very many thanks again for your patience and advice.
creator: sheffner

content: Free beer all around! I'm glad all is okay.
creator: davidsk

content:
Dorothy’s Hello there we have read your message. We try to help you.

you're talking about messages on Thunderbird where you can get them checked in the inbox? okay. something like this could be done with references on your personal computer. With the relevant recycle bin itself. Using a submap in the profile folder or on the desktop. Sounds like a homemade gadget tool.

With certain redirects from Thunderbird Recycle Bin to a specific folder in your personal computer?

It is indeed possible to use a percent of a directory/ profile map. to use it to redirect one directory to another.

if you offer Thunderbird recyclebin a redirect which would not be legal it could cause problems. for example mountains of data for the expensive server , disk space.

Greetings firefoxvolunteer.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Hello there


Tools menu > account settings >server settings and change the local action to whatever folder you like. Your IMAP server will take no notice. Nor will your phone or other devices

It's some kind of way that allows outside of the notifications from one or Thunderbird's server.

To do this, you first need to make sure that a folder exists that contains this trash (bin) folder will be functional and and is well prepared.

Tools menu > account settings > server settings and change the local action to whatever folder you like. Your IMAP server will take no notice. Nor will your phone or other devices

the trash is not intended for storage of emails, indeed it could cause other malfunctions if it acts as or with such behavior that can occur when using it.

above all, you are asked to use an imap account if you use this Thunderbird software like this.

Use a antivirus while internet is on is a good thing.

Greetings firefoxvolunteer.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Hello there

A folder for multiple accounts? how many accounts would that be? if I may ask? And which accounts should that be by name? Of which type?

Do not use more then 3 redirectmaps in a redirect chain.

Greetings Firefox volunteer
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Thank you, Googlethunderbird.

I have six POP email accounts, no IMAP ones. What I'm trying to do is to mark (let's say) a message in Account #1, a second one in Account #2, and a third one in Account #3 as junk. Normally, once I do this, the message from Account #1 goes into the "junk" folder for Account # 1; that for Account #2 goes into the "junk" folder for Account #2; and that for #3 goes into the "junk" folder for Account #3. I'd like to have a combined "junk folder" where I can see all three of them in the the way all of my inboxes are combined in a "unified folder."
creator: DorothyJ

content:
Hello there dorthyJ.

trash are difficult maps to redirect or not at all. If possible, you can redirect them to any folder you want.

your trash folders will work in a similar way.

to be able to share the folder in question you will have to use a different method.


https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/dangerous-directories-Thunderbird-account-settings

On your personal computer

Right-click the folder, and then click [Sharing and Security]. On the [Sharing] tab, select . Share this folder Click Permissions.

Greetings Firefox. Volunteer
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Thank you, Firefox Volunteer.

1. I don't have "Sharing and Security" when I right-click (even when I do so on my inbox).

2. This may or may not be quite what I'm looking for. I'd like to be able to empty what I send to trash (or junk) all at once, not having to do so for each account that I have. That's why I'm looking for a unified folder like the one for the inboxes. If I send anything from the unified inbox to trash (or junk), it goes there -- no matter what account it's from. I can highlight multiple emails, all from different accounts, and trash or junk them all at once. I'd like to be able to empty all of my trash or junk the same way -- all accounts in one swoop. Assuming I had the ability to share, if I were to set up all but one of my (let's just say) trash folders and set all of the rest of them to share to the outstanding one, and then empty the outstanding one, would all of the messages in the other trash folders be deleted? Assume I shared my trash folders from accounts A, B, and C to the trash folder in D. I then emptied the trash folder in D. Would the trash in the A, B, and C folders empty at the same time?
creator: DorothyJ

content: Why not use unified folders view. It does this by default placing a top level folder with all other like top level folders. You only see the sub folders if you choose to.

I was just making the statement that I really liked a lot of things about Eudora that Thunderbird is missing, and there's nothing in Thunderbird that I prefer over what's in Eudora. It wasn't only this situation. I fought it for years -- even had Dell change my registry every time I got a new computer; they had to do that in order for Eudora to install. I really, really miss it!

creator: gmwtexas

content:
I wonder why anyone wants to bounce junk, or any other mail that has already been accepted for delivery.

I know there are some products that claim to do so. They are also logically flawed in that the bounce comes way after the server accepts the mail for delivery. Email, despite what some folk think is mostly automated. So when you send an email to a server for delivery and ask it to deliver mail for XXX@somedomain. The first thing the server does, after deciding if it is accepting mail from that server address, is to check the user exists and refuse to accept the mail is the user does not exist or issue a bounce. Right then, not in a few minutes time, let alone hours.

So the "bounce" that comes in hours after the mail was accepted, unless it is a delayed delivery notice, is clearly some sort of fake. Either from mailwasher or it's ilk, or perhaps generated by malware using your address to send SPAM. To be ignored regardless as a spurious message if you are a spammer. If you are a commercial marketer, you might take a little notice, but you will not place much faith in old or delayed bounce messages.

Then there is the primary reason "bouncing" is bad, and that is true spammers rarely use their own email address. They tend to use addresses harvested from social media Ipso facto the sender that gets this "bounce" has never heard of you and has no idea what you are on about. They are generally confused as they have never even heard of backscatter. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backscatter_(email) and resent receiving it. They might even report you as a spammer.

Then there is the reality that spammers also generally do not monitor failure to deliver. They send out millions, or even billions of emails knowing only a very small percentage of those will ever get to a humans eyeballs. That small percentage is enough to pay their bills, that is all they care about. Mostly they don't see the bounces anyway.

Through fake or "borrowed" from: addresses and sometime using unsecured relay servers, they are largely invisible to the average user and sometime even forensic analysis is difficult as they also include faked headers to obfuscate the true source of the email. So your laborious manual process of sending backscatter to someone that really is not involved is not productive going forward, but could well see your address or server reported for the unsolicited bounce messages (most commercial servers no longer issue them routinely because they are a source of having your server blacklisted for sending SPAM). Remember SPAM is simply unsolicited email.

Then there is the final issue, SPAM is generally unwanted email. But unwanted email is not all SPAM. If you subscribed to it it is not SPAM. Many of the folk I see here talking about SPAM actually are talking about unwanted email from commercial entities they subscribed to. This is not SPAM. It is the commercial relationship between you and the owner of the web site to provide you access. In this scenario, they man act on bounces by simply terminating web site access as your address no longer exists.

If you don't want this commercial email, unsubscribe, close your account on the web site or block all email from the domain with a rule. But it is not SPAM, don't try and treat it as such.

Interestingly, I have accounts with all of the providers you mentioned and by far the one delivering the most SPAM is Yahoo and this has been the case for most of the last 25 years. They have done a rather poor job with SPAM, even Hotmail does better, and they used to back down to anyone that threatened to sue them for treating their mail as SPAM. Such is the US legal system apparently
creator: MattAuSupport
